body: Linking to feature request https://github.com/spf13/cobra/issues/371.
Travis failed due to API GW timing issue.  PR #1650 is required before this PR will pass Travis.

```
[09:21:09 ~]$ wsk api-experimental list
ok: APIs
Action                            Verb             API Name  URL
/james.thomas@uk.ibm.com_dev/weather     get                    /  https://1ed629eb-8082-45c8-970e-10a7280231ca-gws.api-gw.mybluemix.net/api/weather
```

It's not an issue, it's a known limitation and we are aware of it. Currently application/json in application/json out. And were trying our best to get an MVP out and this didn't make the cut, until gateway service supports this type of things.

This makes me think we should add link per bullet in the [apigateway docs](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/apigateway.m) for the feedback and limitations that we are already aware and evaluating.

**Only Content Type application/json is supported for request and response.**

Ref:
```
Note: This feature is currently an experimental offering that enables users an early opportunity to try it out and provide feedback. The following feedback has already been received:
No ability to control HTTP access control for Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS).
**Only Content Type application/json is supported for request and response.**
No programatic way to control the response from the OpenWhisk action.
All OpenWhisk actions are expose via public access, no ability to configure a custom API key.
Path parameters are not supported, only query parameter and request body.
If the API is created without an API name, the name will be the base path and this cannot be changed
When re-creating APIs via input file, the API needs to be deleted first.
When exporting APIs this contain your OpenWhisk API key, this information is sensitive, no templating available.
```

Agreed it's not an "issue". It's a "feature request".
Do you want to collect these here or somewhere else?

I want to collect them in Github.
Hum not sure how best to track.

What you think if we have a TopLevel Github Issues to track all as a bullet feedback, and then a individual issue per each and a link to it.
when there is new feedack we can edit the toplevel comment on the toplevel github issue.

I've seen other projects use a label (feature-request) and a label for the project component (api-gateway) to track these things. That might be easier to maintain the having to manually update a top-level ticket?

ha better idea we already have a `apigw` label and `feedback` label we can use both.

In the issue you can give it a more user point of view of what would be the use case that feature request would support if implemented.

In the meta-API extensions that we recently added, we applied a precedence order: package parameters -> action parameters -> query parameters -> post parameters (last wins). We can adopt the same precedence order and it would make supporting this feature not particularly time consuming.

Not sure what scaffolding you are referring. There is nothing in the packages repos to re-use.

But I agree with the stage approach and do not build the docker container during travis build, we should pull down the docker image from docker hub.

It's super easy to configure docker hub automatic builds with github webhooks, we are already doing this with the trigger providers.
It's all done in docker hub, it needs a github repo with and then we configure the image per repo, to be build when ever there is a git commit or a tag created, we are using tags in providers.

For example we could have the following repos:
```
openwhisk-runtime-nodejs
openwhisk-runtime-swift
openwhisk-runtime-python
```

closing as duplicate.

@csantanapr, can you explain this one more? I'm not sure what `wsk action copy` is?

`wsk action create X --copy Y` is a way to create action `X` by copying the `exec` from action `Y`. It does not copy parameters or annotations from `Y` to `X`. The suggestion above was to make the copy more complete.

1. [ ] controller related changes

Is there any update on this request?

It seems OpenWhisk should prescribe the OAuth integration or even implement some of it under the covers for actions.

An action is likely to be part of an OAuth machine-to-machine interaction pattern (grant_type=client_authorization) . It may simply receive an access token that it has to pass along to the next action in a sequence, or simple accept and validate the token from a caller. It seems there is a need for a build-in mechanism to receive such token and also for retrieving the introspection URL of a provider to validate a token.
Assigned @starpit to comment as he has some experience working with this (and also how to use OAuth to provide a wsk login mecahnism).
@rabbah, Travis keeps failing due to the job taking too long. PG2 1665 is approved.
Passed in pg2/814. @johnsolm  Good to merge. Travis times out, so did the override with pgapproved.

Hi @nastacio,

We should be able to augment the backend and CLI to support oauth logins. Initially, I am imagining that this won't support any kind of grouping; rather, we could initially support authenticating **individual users** against known oauth identity providers, such as github and google.

One of the tricky points here, especially viz. an open source project such as OpenWhisk, would be in supporting the secrets:

1. For each identity provider, the maintainer of a production OpenWhisk installation would need to allocate a (id,secret) pair. This we can address via documentation. In an ideal world, we could offer scripting support for this, but perhaps we can start with documentation.

2. The more complex issue is the **support for continuous integration**.  In particular, how can we support Travis tests against PRs? Do we allocate a set of test **(id,secret)** pairs, and store them in the Travis key store? Does this violate the open source nature of OpenWhisk, to have secrets such as this? And what about localhost testing?

Or, do we make a set of (id,secret) pairs public, stating forcefully that one must not depend on these for production installations?

Finally, to test the full login path, from wsk client through the server-side backend (and back), we would *also* need to have a set of user login credentials, so that the test client can log on to the identity providers. This raises mostly the same issues as with the (id,secret) pair, perhaps with some additional concerns; e.g. fine, we can make an (id,secret) pair public, for testing purposes, but surely we can't make a github or google login credential public...

What are we gaining with this? Shouldn't the exception go uncaught anyway and thus be logged by gradle/JUnit whomever?

Yes except there could be two exceptions and the last masks the first. Here was the thought behind this maybe it leads to something better. Suppose a create failed within the asset helper - this would throw an exception which is caught by the try. But then the cleaner throws an exception also because the delete will fail as well. So you don't see the exception from the create.

JSON file input support exists in the CLI currently. The encoding support does not, however.
 
`  -P, --param-file FILE,   FILE containing parameter values in JSON format`

hi @dubeejw thanks for the response. we need something more than that. think of the case of an XML document as input to an action invocation. the XML document needs to be stringified (after all, it has double quotes!) before it can be passed as input to an openwhisk action.

yes, i could script this externally, but i think it'd be nice to just have this support directly in the CLI.

it gets even more messy when considering non-ascii encodings.

here is how i ended up invoking my action with a utf-16 xml document as input:
```
% echo "{\"xmlInput\": "`iconv --unicode-subst=formatstring -f utf-16 -t us-ascii < sample.xml | node conv.js`"}" > in.json
% wsk action invoke cogdigity/export2json --param-file in.json
```

notice the use of: 1) `iconv`, and 2) a nodejs program to help with stringifying (i could've used sed or awk here, i just gave up trying to figure out the escaping of escaping of escaping... nonsense)
the param file also requires one to modify the file to nest the payload into a json property - i does not quite satisfy the feature requested here even if you set aside the encoding.
We're now completely broken w.r.t. Travis CI - can't get a clean PRs and master failing on occasion too.

perhaps now is the time to introduce a 'quick' build for travisCI, that doesn't build/test everything.    Jenkins would still run 'normal' builds.

'quick' build could e.g. elide swift and python.

Your comments seem to be covering the (welcome) addition of OAuth to the existing "HTTP Basic" security for the CLI, but I am talking specifically about machine-to-machine integration versus end-users (or developers) initiating an action.

I am after two patterns:

A) an action needs to pass an OAuth bearer token to a 3rd party in order to perform an action (e.g. direct message someone on Twitter) 

B) a vendor providing an action wants the action to be a resource secured via OAuth so that they don't have to hand out a static (and global) pair of user id / password to consumers.

For #A, it is prohibitively expensive for an action to go through the OAuth choreography with an OAuth Provider (OP) to secure an access token for each call. Additionally, there is the configuration nightmare of refreshing an access token, where the action also needs the introspection/refresh endpoint for the OP. That seems an area where the solution needs to reside outside the action code.

For #B, conceptually that is just an addition to the existing "Authorization" header in the invocation of the action via endpoints, though it does entail costly provisions at the OpenWhisk installation level (manage client id/secrets) . 

I am not immediately interested in #B, though I can see how people thinking of monetizing the access to their actions have a legitimate need for separate sets of credentials per customer. They definitely would not want to pay for CPU time in building the authorization layer inside their action code.

Agree - this is a duplicate of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/373.

```
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# make sure you're using the go cli
export PATH=~/bin:$PATH

echo "function main(params) { return { name: "Step1 " + params.name }}" > foo.js

# clean up (don't care about errors here)
wsk action delete foos >& /dev/null
wsk action delete foop/foo >& /dev/null
wsk package delete foop >& /dev/null

which wsk | grep -vi python && \
    wsk package create foop && \
    wsk action create foop/foo foo.js && \
    wsk -v action create --sequence foos foop/foo,foop/foo
```
i suspect this will probably affect rules that name actions in packages too.

The only way the above can happen is if your namespace is set to nothing in ~/.wskprops. Ie, `NAMESPACE=`.
Run `wsk property unset --namespace` then try again.
i have `NAMESPACE=`, i.e. with nothing but a newline after the equals. and i have the latest version of the go cli (according to the md5 sum -- is there a better way to check?)
It should be `NAMESPACE=_`.

Taken from another issue opened by me:

## Problem statement

Currently we support a fixed number of runtimes in OpenWhisk "natively". That means a user can upload an artifact specific to the language (i.e. a code snipped) and we will treat it as needed by that language (compile it, run it).

While this is all good, the approach doesn't scale from a CI/CD point of view. We're currently hitting the 50 minute mark in Travis repeatedly and even with that off the table, our build times will just increase over time as we add new runtimes. Building the different runtimes, especially Swift currently, has a big impact on our overall build time. It also impacts first-time contributors as the time to "just deploy the system locally" increases.
## Proposed solution

We could add a plugin system for runtimes and only ship OpenWhisk with a default runtime (Node.js for example). We benefit from this in multiple ways:
1. Build and testtime for just the _core_ system decreases. As we only test what's common for every language. I think it makes sense to define at least one language as being the default though, to facilitate end-to-end testing and have a better test-coverage for that core system.
2. It's easier for contributors to add new runtimes, as they likely don't have to touch the core components.
## Thoughts on design

To implement this we could make runtimes part of the configuration. That configuration would then include the different properties of each runtime, included in `Exec.scala` today.

The configuration needs to be able to tell the system which _image_ to use and which properties to expect for each of the runtimes (Node.js for example takes `code`, Java takes a `.jar` file).
#1675 implements @sjfink's proposal + a bit more.
